At 23:15 26/01/2005, you wrote:

[...]

>probably 10 years here but one case of this was Roger Penrose's book
>Shadows Of The Mind in which he attempts to prove mathematically that
>conciousness cannot be described by an algorithm. He then goes on to
>suggest that neuron mitochondria may be somehow describing a much finer
>(than relatively large neurons) information processing network that
>operates at the quantum physical level, perhaps tapping into some
>unknown physical dimension.
>
>Now, while it's an interesting idea it was my interpretation that the
>book was effectively saying that conciousness is something which is
>supernatural and mysterious and it just feels like passing the buck to me.

In "The Emperor's New Mind" he tries to link consciousness with quantum 
wave function collapse.

I get the impression he's against materialism and prepared to try any 
explanation to support his preconception.

> >We know that almost all known chemical and physicial processes proceed in a
> >predetermined direction.  (i.e.  If you were to rewind time and start it
> >playing again - the chemical/physical processes would proceed almost
> >*exactly* the same.  I say almost - because new quantum theory suggests
> >there is a level of inherent unpredictability which might suggest different
> >outcomes.)
> >
> >
>Having recently done some reading on pseudo random number generators it
>makes me wonder if the universe may be using such a generator ;)  And if
>we could perhaps work out the algorithm, hmm :)

I believe this is a variation of the "hidden variables" explanation for 
quantum indeterminacy, but I think there is a proof that it is not the 
case.  Something to do with the EPR paradox I think...
Now consider that crocs have been around for millions of years without

>hardly changing from an evolutionary point of view. Perhaps they have
>reached the pinacle of what they can achieve without something
>equivalent to the frontal cortex of our brain, which is something which
>evolved after the limibic system but communicates very closely with it.
>This new brain system takes in the same information but is able to
>provide a new level of processing that the limbic system was incapable
>of, like make memories and associations between them.

Or perhaps they have reached a pinnacle, period.  It is a mistake to equate 
"higher organism" with "fitter organism", or even "better 
organism".  Bacteria are just as highly evolved as we are, only for a 
different game.  Crocs also...

>It might sound silly but I don't think conciousness is an on/off thing
>that is generated by some specific part of the brain, I think it's a
>consequence of more and more information about our surroundings being
>processed in an ordered manner to drive our behaviour/survival - the
>more deep and abstract the information, the deeper the level of
>conciousness.

I used to have a friend (may still, but haven't seen him for years) who 
thought everything was conscious but to different degrees.  ISRT we had a 
very long (and drunken) argument over whether there was any consciousness 
in the bar stool he was sitting on.

I completely rejected that approach at first, but the more I think about 
it, the more I come down to a choice between two approaches:

1) consciousness will be a very specific process that the brain performs
2) everything _is_ conscious, but a coherent data processing system gets a 
_lot_ more out of it than a piece of furniture

I still tend towards (1), however.

>Taking the idea a step further, yes it is emergent but you can't just
>put a load of unordered complex systems together  and hope for
>emergence. The interface between the systems has to be ordered, and
>survival of the fittest just happens to have come up with just such an
>ordered system of info processing.

Absolutely.

> >This observation suggests that a large enough and complex enough network
> >could experience this emergent property.  The Internet itself could *think*
> >it is sentient - despite the fact that, like us, its thoughts are
> >predetermined.  This approach has interesting and dour predictions for
> >communication between species.
> >
> >
>The internet is an intersting case to ponder. Think I'll leave that for
>another day :)

I have Jan 3rd, 3048 put aside for this question, shall we meet somewhere?

         Ian
